body:
@ewencp I made some updates today, and I think this is ready for another pass
- Local laptop: retain original default `enable_hostmanager` setting, so you have the option, but are not required to use `vagrant/vagrant-up.sh`
- AWS: can use the wrapper script for both worker cluster, and zk/broker cluster use cases
- However, parallel bringup with zk/broker nodes (i.e. non-workers) is problematic, so this remains serial
@pyr Looks like this KIP is going to pass! Would you mind rebasing?
@ewencp Addressed review comments. The reason for changing `listConnectors` to static is that the method does not depend on any state of `AbstractHerder`. Should be good to take another look.
Tests pass locally. Review by @gwenshap.
Tested and validated that the compilation warnings are all needed. LGTM.
Ping @ijuma @miguno @gwenshap for reviews. I suggest this patch to be merged in trunk before 0.10.0 branch cut.

I reverted the changes to Schema and Struct to workaround the incompatibility of nullable fields and default values. It was getting complex and it felt like the wrong solution. Really all we need is a way to be able to set null values for nullable fields. We can't do it only because we can't distinguish a null value from an absent value. I talked with @junrao and we were thinking that the best short-term solution is to leave off the default value for the metadata field and address this problem after the release.

@guozhangwang: I am reviewing, but I think moving forward we should begin to have atomic PRs -- this PR conflates three distinct functionality changes (1. overloading functions w.r.t serialization, 2. changes to Streams config setup, 3. timestamp extractor).
cc @SinghAsDev
Tests pass locally, but I still have to write a test that fails before these changes.
@fpj I addressed your comments and updated the code.
@ijuma Good point. Turns out the original code, even though checking version 0, was using the v1 constructor.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM. Wait to see if we can add a test easily.

@miguno Yes I used to have atomic PRs, but due to the fact that 1) we are having a hard deadline for 0.10.0 branch cut and 2) review round-trip takes longer due to time zone difference, I'm merging multiple ones into one to shorten the period. This is just a one-time thing.

@ijuma I will rebase and look at supporting the idea of `null` (versus empty list) indicating that you don't want to request topic metadata at all. Its a bit nuanced, but its the most compatible and has fewer edge cases. Worst case scenario if someone passes an empty list is performance. This would help solve [KAFKA-3358](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3358).

@enothereska These look fine, they are being discovered now. I did a quick scan for others we may have messed up the naming for and one more shows up -- tests/kafkatest//tests/consumer_rolling_upgrade.py. Want to just roll that into this fix as well?
@ewencp sure, done.

@enothereska Oops, don't think we want to move `produce_consume_validate.py`. It is (perhaps confusingly) in `tests/` but is a base class for tests -- moving it breaks a bunch of imports that use it and removes a bunch of tests.
Good catch @ewencp thanks!
Great, LGTM!
Thanks for the reviews @miguno @ewencp , merged to trunk.
@ijuma I rebased and added the "no topics" functionality.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
Invite @ewencp @gwenshap for reviews.
Unit test passed locally. LGTM and merged to trunk.
@pyr Time is short for 0.10, so I'm going to go ahead and rebase and submit a new PR. You'll still get credit for the patch.

@granthenke looks like the concurrency test fails because of too many attempts (one of the latest changes) :

```
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Failed to update ACLs for Topic:test after trying a maximum of 15 times)
```

I suppose that for any number you choose, there is a chance that the test case will need that number or more, which is a bit concerning because it can keep running for some time. I think we will need to back off in the case of collision, like with a random sleep if you want something simple. Perhaps you have a better idea?
Writing a test for this is proving to be difficult. `connect` always returns `false` while connecting to `EchoServer` on localhost on my mac.
Sorry, noticed a bit late that this PR includes protocol changes that didn't go through a community discussion. Lets make sure there are 3 committers who are ok with the protocol modification?

@fpj Causing collisions is the point of the test. It verifies that the code always maintains the correct state no matter how many retries it takes. I really don't want to over engineer this and I don't think this is a real world issue. The test just goes to extremes to prove ACLs are never lost. Do you feel strongly about the arbitrary retry limit code?

@granthenke Even if this loops forever, this is just AclCommand running, right? In the very worst case of running for too long due to collisions, you'd have to kill it and try again. There is little harm in not having the retries if that's the case, unless it is problem that you're not sure whether the ACL change has gone through or not, but I suppose you can check if needed.

I still think that it'd be better to back off in the case of collisions rather than running in a tight loop, but I don't want to block this issue on it. Perhaps we can create a jira and work on it later.

@fpj I can add a backoff over the next few days. Its only quick in the test because we are on an EmbeddedZookeeper. In the real world the read of the data happens before the next update request which slows things down.
FYI: new PR is #1098
LGTM. Waiting for tests to finish before merging.
@gwenshap @Ishiihara @hachikuji Need a review on this -- it's pretty straightforward though. We have similar code in Confluent's rest-utils, but here it is even properly tested!
Passed on my machine (I'm impatient!)
Merging. Feel free to add tests after the branch cutting - tests don't add risk by definition :)
@gwenshap Updated to test when we don't have CORS enabled -- it won't fail the request, it's just going to not return the header.
LGTM
LGTM
ping @gwenshap
@fpj I added a simple backoff with a random jitter
LGTM. Thanks for catching and fixing, @junrao :)

Looks AMAZING too me. Hopefully @miguno can comment on the docs quality, since he has better context.

In a separate PR, perhaps document the possible exceptions?
LGTM
LGTM
@granthenke I think this was the same issue as KAFKA-3427?

LGTM. 
Test failure unrelated (and looks like a Jenkins issue) - validated tests on my machine.

I love the new concurrency tests util - should be very handy in the future.

It is probably a bit arbitrary - the automation scripts will need to know how many partitions to add just to avoid the "can't reduce number of partitions" error...

I don't mind changing the behavior (since changing error to non-error won't break existing automation), but the code modification is a bit convoluted:
We now check nPartitions both inside "addPartitions" and after calling it. Lets do all the checks either inside the method or before calling it?
@gwenshap this is for the Java class, that one was for the Scala one.
@granthenke, it looks like this needs to be rebased.
@guozhangwang, can you please review this?

@llowrey spotted a problem in #1094, this PR is an attempt at fixing that.

Review by @llowrey and @junrao.
LGTM
@ijuma @gwenshap @junrao rebased the patch
LGTM
My load tests pass with this change and fail without it.
Thanks for checking @llowrey.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
bumping this so it doesn't get lost or left in limbo. @granthenke, do you know what steps remain for getting more committers eyes on this for eventual merge/release?

@ewencp Apologies for the delay. I've tried to fix the race condition with task shutdown, but the synchronization in WorkerTask is getting complex. If it seems OK now, maybe we can plan to revisit it later.

LGTM.
The patch looks fine, but I may be missing a higher level point: What's the difference between the internal BrokerEndPoint and the external Node? They seem to contain identical fields...
@becketqin @junrao  I have updated the patch as discussed. Can you review again?
@hachikuji, can you please file a JIRA for this so that we can track it for release purposes? It would be good to include it in 0.10.0.0. cc @gwenshap

Thanks for the PR.

Looks like this is fine in trunk:

https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/common/network/Selector.java#L129

No new releases are planned for the 0.8.x series, so I think we are no longer merging PRs for that branch.

@gwenshap That's a very good point. My aim was to avoid introducing a new public class that's only used in our request classes. Using `Node`, which is already used in `MetadataResponse` achieves that goal while reducing code duplication so here's an alternative PR: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1105

You get to choose which one you prefer. :) Once you do, I'll close the other PR and update the JIRA to reflect what we actually merged in the end.
This is an alternative to https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1102 as per @gwenshap's suggestion.

Hi @gwenshap - my PR has the checks on numPartitions are still all inside Adminutils.addPartitions method.
While the println are still only in TopicCommand.alterTopic, so I am not sure what change you're suggesting. Checking on the number of partitions added (returned by addPartitions) seems the only way to print a conditional message.
@junrao Would you be able to review this pull request prior to the 0.10 release?
cc @ijuma @gwenshap @junrao @ewencp
This seems to be a simple change and it includes tests, so LGTM.

@zhuchen1018 : Thanks for the patch. I am actually not sure if we should patch the handling of response parsing error this way. If the parsing fails due to a Kafka bug, we should just fix the bug in the source. Otherwise, we'd expect the parsing of the receive to always succeed and there is no need to add any additional logic.

When there is a bug that causes parsing to fail, currently, we just throw an exception back to the caller. This is probably what we want, instead of hiding the error from the user. Also, the patch makes the code more complicated. For example, I am not if we should add failReceive() to Selector since the parsing failure happens at NetworkClient level.
I'm not sure we want this behavior -- it's different than the behavior of `java.util.Properties` which seems like it will just be confusing.
@onurkaraman : Do you want to take a look? @noslowerdna : This is probably not an 0.10.0 blocker since we now recommend people to use the new java consumer, which doesn't have that constraint.
@junrao Do we recommend that yet? I think it was decided not to remove the beta tag for 0.10 on the consumer. ([KAFKA-3283](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3283))

@ewencp That's true. The current behaviour is also really confusing (`java.util.Properties` is broken due to its inheritance model) though. Maybe we should introduce a method with a different name and use that instead of the discouraged `containsKey`.
My recommendation is to just leave the code in NetworkClient/Selector as it is and just let unexpected exceptions be propagated back to the caller.
@becketqin : Since we will be cutting the 0.10.0 release today, I recommend that we just leave this out of 0.10.0 if we don't have a patch ready in the next few days.
@becketqin @zhuchen1018, Given Jun's comment, should we move this JIRA out of the 0.10.0.0 release?
@granthenke : The issue listed there (KAFKA-3177) seems rare. Given that we have cleaned the new consumer api, my feeling is that the new consumer is ready for production usage.
@ijuma Will do.
@junrao sure. I'll take a look at it.
Here is the JIRA: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3434. I'll close this and reopen it under that JIRA's name.

We are phasing out VerifiableProperties in favor of KafkaConfig (it only exists because we still keep the old consumer and producer around AFAIK). So, either way doesn't matter too much - we are about 6 month away from getting rid of the old clients and this will go with that.
Thanks!

@gwenshap I have not reproduced the issue, but it is evident from the stacktrace on the JIRA. NoSuchElementException gets thrown in `topicPartitionAssignment.head._2.size`. This happens when topic exists, but there are no partitions. I think you are looking at wrong branch, the ST is for 0.9.0.1 branch, https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/0.9.0/core/src/main/scala/kafka/admin/TopicCommand.scala#L198. Helps?

@junrao The current code does not propagate the exception to the caller thread, right? We catch all unknown exception in the sender thread and just move on. The caller will not be notified. In our case, the caller thread was just blocked on flush() forever. With the patch, the request will eventually be timed out, so user will receive exception in the callback.
@junrao Sure, I will try to make the patch ready as soon as possible. But I agree this probably should not block 0.10.0 release. I will change the ticket to critical instead of blocker.
Merged to both trunk and 0.10.0.
LGTM
LGTM
Should this update the "Quick Start" download link in `quickstart.html` and the JavaDoc link in `api.html`? or is that a separate change?
well never mind...got committed while looking at it.
@gwenshap Was this part of, or all of [KAFKA-3441](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3441)?
Good points @granthenke - since I have another cleanup to do, I'll fix it there :)
@ewencp @junrao when you have a sec :)

Ping @guozhangwang @ewencp for review.

This patch changes the asynchronous commit behavior to try and force the send during the commitAsync() call itself. Prior to this patch, we simply queued the commit to be sent in poll(), which causes send failures because NetworkClient doesn't allow more than one request to be sent on each invocation of poll() and ConsumerNetworkClient simply fails the rest. Based on my testing, this makes the problem go away in practice and also has the nice side effect of allowing heartbeats to be sent in commitAsync().
